awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Midwest Low KV Collaboration: Continuation of Development of Low KV High Spatial Resolution EPMA Technique to Sub-micron Geological Features
awd_abstract_narration:
This project involves development of new techniques in the use of the electron probe microanalyzer, to extend its usefulness in chemically analyzing smaller sized materials than previously possible. This instrument operates by focusing a beam of high energy electrons at a target sample inside a vacuum chamber, and then measuring the different X-rays inherently produced by this process.  The rationale for this work is to better understand physical processes - both in geological and earth materials, but also in man-made materials at smaller and smaller scales - with a relatively simple instrument that is available in many universities, industrial and governmental research laboratories. Many times the very smallest features in a material can give critical information about how the material was created, and for manmade materials, how it will break or fail.

In a just completed NSF-supported project  (EAR-1554269), to develop a technique for extending the utility of the smaller electron beam field emission electron probe microanalyzer, we operated at lower accelerating voltage (i.e., 7 kV) vs traditional 15-20 kV. At these voltages, the higher energy K-series X-ray lines such those of the transition metals (e.g. Fe), are not generated - requiring that the lower energy L-series X-rays be measured and quantified. However, there are series difficulties with using these L-series X-rays, as they become complex entities due to spectral peak shift/shape changes, resulting from chemical bonding effects exacerbated by the adjacent absorption edge which adds more complexity. Thus, one single or simple reference standard is no longer a valid approach to quantification. In that project, we developed an innovative procedure to handle these iron L-alpha X-rays--and iron is an important element in many relevant geological materials. This research focused on the Fe-bearing mineral olivine and iron-silicides (found in meteorites and on the surface of the moon). This new project has several components to extend this technique: (1) extend this low kV Fe-L series work to other important important minerals such as sulfides, pyroxenes, garnets and amphiboles, (2) expand to look at L-lines of some Ni-bearing and Mn-rich minerals, (3) evaluate possible ways to improve measurements with "plasma" cleaning samples, (4) develop protocols using the innovative Soft X-ray Emission Spectrometer for the low energy X-rays generated at low kV, (5) investigate the feasibility of utilizing DFT (density functional theory) to simulate the complex spectral shapes of the L-series transition metals as well as the M-series of some rare earth elements (which have a similar set of conditions as the L-lines of Fe, etc.), and (6) investigate sample damage by the higher-electron-density field emission beam. This work will be done in a joint collaboration between the electron microprobe labs of the University of Wisconsin-Madison and the University of Minnesota-Minneapolis.  The project will support a postdoctoral research fellow.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project's theme is determining the chemical composition of very small (~micron scale) features, using a high energy beam of electrons, which cause X-rays to be created in the targeted material. Detectors count the X-rays and software processes the counts to output the elemental composition. Our study has focused upon iron-bearing materials, and mainly geological materials.

The specific electron beam instrument is the electron microprobe (or electron probe microanalyzer, EPMA). The instruments can also scan, or raster, the beam side to side (like old-fashioned CRT televisions) and produce very nice pictures of the small features and their surrounding materials, as secondary electron (SEI) images or backscattered electron (BSE) images

This technique has been around since ~1950, with electron energies of 15,000-20,000 electron volts  (15-20 keV)  used, and a given set of energies/ wavelengths of the generated X-rays commonly used. Using these energies, the smallest feature that can be typically analyzed is 2-3 microns in size when the beam energy is 15-20 keV. This is pretty small--a human hair is around 70 microns wide. But smaller is better !

However, in the past 2 decades, a new technology has migrated to the electron microprobe, replacing the old-school tungsten electron source, with a field emission electron source, which can create pictures 10-100x or more sharper than the old tungsten source. With this ability to see smaller features sharply in SE or BSE images, the logical question became: can features smaller than 2-3 microns be chemically analyzed? The answer is YES, but only if lower energy electron beams are used--in the range of 5,000 to 10,000 keV. 

There is a serious problem however, when you use a low beam energy such as 5-7 keV. The traditionally used iron X-ray line is one at 6.4 keV (K-alpha) but to generate it, the beam must break the inner shell electron bond which can only occur if the beam energy is at or above 7.1 keV. So the microanalysist must now switch to using a lower energy X-ray line, from a different electron shell, specifically on at .7 keV ("L-alpha"). 

The purpose of this project was to continue prior EAR-1849386 project, to extend the technique to additional geological material--sulfides, economically important minerals--as well as develop appropriate software to assist EPMA researchers. Using the traditional software programs, clearly erroneous results are generated for the low keV iron L X-ray lines. This is mainly due to problems with accurately knowing one of the essential correction factors, the "mass absorption coefficients" (MACs).

We showed that there are two alternative approaches which produce improved results for most sulfide mineral types at low keV. One is to use a generally ignored smaller X-ray peak which serendipitously does not have the problem with essentially impossible-to-accurately-determine MACs. Its small size is a bit problematic, as precision of measurement varies with the number of counts, so less counts make less precise measurements--but they are generally pretty accurate (on target for known reference materials). The other technique is involves several differences from the "normal" EPMA data-handling procedure. Normal EPMA measures only the middle channel of the actually wider X-ray peak, as in general EPMA, that single middle channel is representative the of the X-ray intensity of the whole wide peak--it is a question of time, as measuring one channel is much, much faster than measuring the whole peak--in the normal "wavelength dispersive spectrometer" (WDS)  X-ray detector on the electron microprobe. And something we've not mentioned before is that the EPMA procedure is "standards-based", so that there must always be a reference material measured together with the unknown material.  Our new procedure makes this simiple, as we predicate the use of pure iron metal (not typically used EPMA of minerals) AND we measure the whole peaks. Doing this, we have created calibration curves which we have discovered are UNIVERSAL for all electron microprobes using spectrometers sitting at a 40? "take-off angle", which is commonly the case. This produces pretty good results.

Software that was developed: WiscResolution is a GUI to determine the analytical spatial resolution (for each X-ray from the sample) with these variables: keV, geometry of target material and surrounding matrix, beam diameter. BadgerFilm is a general purpose matrix correction program useful for determining thin film compositions, both important in materials science and engineering but here useful for being able to correct for coatings and films impacting EPMA at low keV, where surfaces of the unknown material can affect the accuracy of the measurement. These programs are freely available (from the PI or from https://github.com/Aurelien354/).  Additional deliverables from this project were publications done with collaborators: Llovet et al 2022, studying the complicated "self absoroption" of iron and other metal L-lines; and Llovet et al 2020, the first major review of EPMA in decades in a major scientific journal.


Last Modified: 07/29/2022
Modified by: John H Fournelle
